message.content: This question requires knowledge of how temperature affects a mercury thermometer. When the temperature increases, the mercury in the thermometer expands and rises up the column. Therefore, an active oven, which generates heat, will cause the mercury in the thermometer to go upwards. Option (A) is incorrect because a higher temperature does not cause the mercury to go lower. Option (B) is incorrect because the speed of the mercury's movement is not relevant to temperature. Option (D) is incorrect because the brightness of the mercury does not change based on temperature.

This question requires basic knowledge about how temperature affects the expansion of mercury in a thermometer. When the oven is active and producing heat, the temperature inside the oven rises. As a result, the mercury in the thermometer expands and moves upwards, indicating a higher temperature. Option (A) is incorrect because an active oven will cause the temperature to rise, not lower. Option (B) is incorrect because the speed at which the mercury rises is not affected by the oven. Option (D) is incorrect because the brightness of the mercury does not change when it is heated by the oven.

This question requires some basic knowledge about how temperature affects the behavior of a thermometer. When an oven is active, it generates heat, which in turn raises the temperature in its surroundings. When the temperature rises, the mercury inside a thermometer expands and rises, indicating a higher temperature. Option (A) is incorrect because the temperature increasing, not decreasing. Option (B) is unrelated to temperature and the behavior of a thermometer. Option (D) is unrelated to temperature and the behavior of a thermometer.

Option (A) is incorrect because heat causes the mercury to rise, not lower. Option (B) is also incorrect because the speed at which the mercury rises is not affected by the oven.
